landing_page.intro_content: Der delegierte Anteilsnachweis als Konsensus Mechanismus, ist die Zukunft smart-contract basierter Blockchain-Netzwerke. Telos bietet eine nachhaltige Lösung, in dem wir die Geschwindigkeit und Skalierbarkeit der EOSIO Software mit echter Dezentralisierung vereinen. Telos hat die gerechteste, und gleichmäßigste Geldverteilung aller Blockchainprojekte, und ist somit vor Korruption des politischen Prozesses geschützt, was mehr Sicherheit und Tragfähigkeit bedeutet.
landing_page.developers_content: Die Telos Plattform existiert zum Zweck der sicheren, stabilen und kosteneffizienten Anwendung von smart-contract basierten Lösungen und dezentralisierten Apps. Günstige RAM Preise erlauben Entwicklern sowohl open-source also auch proprietäre Programme zu schreiben, welche ohne Transaktionskosten laufen können.
landing_page.dpos_content: Das Telos Netzwerk kann eine Rekordgeschwindigkeit von 5'000 Transaktionen pro Sekunde erreichen, was zu massiver Skalierbarkeit führt. Dank des schnellsten dezentralisierten Netzwerkes aller Zeiten, können Dapps weltweite Reichweite erziehen, mit nur 1.5 Sekunden pro Blockverifizierung.
landing_page.gov_content: Telos hat ein reiches Verwaltungssystem, welches von einer Konstitution, bis hin zu regelmäßigen Wahlen von Blockproduzenten und Werkanträgen reicht. Kein anderes Blockchain Netzwerk bietet mehr interne Führungsstruktur und Disputresolution.
landing_page.white_paper_content: Lesen sie das Whitepaper und entscheiden sie selbst. Wir wollen die beste Blockchain aller Zeiten erschaffen. Helfen sie uns, Telos zu bauen.

intro_paragraphs: Telos is a community-led alternative to EOS. We need you to help spread the word and make the Telos Network a success. You can share in the 1 million TLOS community rewards pool.

You can make videos, articles, tweets, posts, tutorials—just about anything that helps spread the word. Meetups, community management and more is all available and receives rewards both for the initial action and when people engage with you by liking, clapping, attending, viewing, whatever.

Once the Telos Network activates, you can submit a final list of your community engagement for your tokens. You can either supply us with your account name, or send us a Telos public key and new account name and we will create the account for you and fill it with your rewards!
Telos is a blockchain where your voice matters, so use that voice to tell everyone about the world changing advantages of the Telos Network.

column_one: All items subject to change and investigation. Gaming the system or getting rewards on a technicality will not be allowed.
Participants must register with the system portal above, providing their user names in the various platforms.
After network activation, participants will submit a final list of links and addresses for verification. Email instructions will be sent to all registered users prior to activation.
column_two: Submissions must be received within one week of Telos network activation
All participants who earn tokens will receive a free Telos Address!
All posts must include links to an official Telos website or Telos social media page:
column_three: All judges' determinations are final and cannot be appealed or arbitrated.
If the total amount earned by participants exceeds the 1 million TLOS allocated, then all timely submissions will be reduced in like percentage to pay each participant a pro rata share.
Participants may not also claim rewards from the Telos Founders Rewards Pool. They can only be a member of one or the other.

intro.heading: Telos Lost Key Recovery Portal
content: Were your keys lost or compromised on EOS? Telos wants to make sure the proper owners receive their TLOS tokens in our upcoming Telos sharedrop!

Telos will give TLOS tokens 1:1 based on the original EOS ERC-20 snapshot (up to 40,000 per account) using the same keys and account names as the EOS genesis. Unfortunately, this means that anyone whose keys were lost or compromised at that time or since that time will also need their keys replaced on the Telos chain. For this reason, we’re working to alert EOS genesis token holders that Telos will allow them to revise their keys where necessary.

The key replacement process needs to occur BEFORE the Telos mainnet launches. Because Telos is using the original ERC-20 snapshot, we can verify ownership based on the Ethereum address that held those keys and can bypass any phishing or other key loss that may have happened to accounts after EOS launched. We have a special window of time in which to help anyone who lost their EOS accounts to maintain control of their new Telos accounts.
To be clear, Telos can only protect lost or compromised genesis accounts on the Telos blockchain. Unfortunately, we have no power to aid lost key issues on EOS accounts

process_one.two_processes_heading: There are two processes for Key Recovery
process_one.heading: PROCESS 1
process_intro: This is the process for any users who registered their EOS ERC-20 tokens but later lost their keys or had them compromised. This will apply to 98% of users so it is probably the right one for you.

You will sign a message on the Ethereum blockchain from the same address that held your EOS tokens at the snapshot. This message will include a new public key that you can generate in any wallet you choose; we show examples here using the Sqrl, the native Telos wallet. Sqrl can create a public key that begins with either EOS or TLOS; the order doesn’t matter.

Be sure to save the private key associated with your new public key. This is how you will access your account! Once you send the message, please send us the Ethereum address and EOS public key you recorded. We will verify the message and change the keys.
process_one.step_one: Use any EOS or Telos wallet, Scatter, Greymass, etc..  We are using SQRL here to demonstrate how to generate a set of keys.

step_two.step: Generate a new set of keys.  (These are for a Telos account.)
screenshot_captions: Open the Sqrl wallet and note the "Generate Key" button marked above.  You do not need to do anything but click this button to start
Selecting "Generate Key" generates a key pair instantly.  This will be the key pair used for your Telos recovery, and it will also be the key you use to access your telos after the sharedrop.

Clicking each key will automatically copy the key to your clipboard. This is the ONLY TIME you will be able to save your key pair. The photo here shows the keys being copy and pasted onto notepad. Your private key should be saved offline (in multiple safe places) and NEVER shared with anyone. If you mistakenly closed out the keypair before saving, no worries. Simply start the process over and save the new key pair.

To review, we have done two things up to this point:

  • Opened the SQRL wallet and clicked "Generate Key"
  • Saved the key pair we generated (both public and private)

Once you have completed the these two steps, you are done with sqrl for the purposes of this guide. The next time you will need to use it will be after telos launches to access your TLOS tokens!

step_three.step: For the next step, you will need to open https://www.myetherwallet.com/signmsg.html and sign into the Ethereum wallet which held your EOS tokens. Here is what this page should look like:
step_three.copy_paste: Next, copy and paste the following into the "message" box (like in the screenshot below):
step_three.message: As the cryptographically verified owner of ethereum address listed below ("Ethereum Address"), I attest that I did own the EOS tokens listed on the EOS ERC-20 snapshot associated with this address and that I hereby request that the public key for my account be changed to the new EOS public key below ("New EOS Public Key") or the Telos Network address equivalent for my corresponding account on the Telos Network. I agree to release the Telos Network and its Members - as well as the members of any blockchain project that may subsequently use this same value snapshot in the future - from any claim arising from this request. The cryptographic signature of this document constitutes my legal digital signature in all jurisdictions.
step_three.screenshot_caption:
Once you have copy and pasted the message, you will need to add one PUBLIC address, or key, to each of the spaces noted in the red boxes above.

  • Your "Ethereum Address" will come from the public address where your EOS was stored at the time of the genesis snapshot. This is the same address you will be logging into to sign this message.
  • Your "New Eos Key" is the public key you generated in Sqrl in Step 1 and saved in Step 2. Simply copy and paste it. If you are confused, this is the top, or first key, in the third screenshot in these directions. The one labeled "pub" on the notepad.

Next, in the area below the message, select whichever ethereum wallet your EOS tokens were in and log in.
step_three.screenshot_caption_two: Once you have logged into your wallet, you will arrive at a page with the option to sign the copy and pasted message with the keys you added to it.  Click "sign message" at the bottom.
step_three.screenshot_caption_three: After signing the message you will arrive at the page below.  To complete the recovery process, please copy (all of) the contents of the "signature" box (noted in red in the screenshot), and paste them into the form below.  Please note, entering your email address in the form is the only way we can reach you if there was an issue with your recovery registration that needs to be addressed.
step_three.email_us: Send us your information so we can research your claim.

process_one.process_note: Note:  No one from Telos will every ask for your private key! If you get an email from us it will only be to help you go through this process again to make sure it works.

process_two.heading: PROCESS 2
process_intro: This process is for people who never registered their EOS ERC-20 tokens with Block One prior to the genesis snapshot. Because you will need to enter your private ethereum keys, we are directing you to EOS Authority. They are a respected block producer and have developed a verified process that will work on the Telos network exactly as it does on the EOS network.
process_two.eos_auth: Go to the EOS Authority web site:
process_two.save_keys: Save those keys for your SQRL wallet account.
process_two.import_wallet: Import wallet through SQRL once network launches.

recovery_form.heading: Please enter your information
recovery_form.email_label: Email (Optional, in case there is a problem)
recovery_form.ethereum_label: Ethereum address where your EOS was stored, where we see your pasted-in message
recovery_form.generated_label: Newly generated Telos (or EOS) address where you would like your TLOS to be sent

intro.heading: Downloads
intro.subheading: Download all the documents and tools that you need to join the Telos Network.

wallets.heading: Telos Wallets
wallets.subheading: Choose a wallet to store and trade your TLOS tokens.
wallets.sqrl_description: Sqrl is a fully functional light wallet designed for the TELOS blockchain. This application can be used to connect to a remote TELOS API endpoint to perform producer voting actions and common wallet commands.

white_paper.description: We are out to create the best blockchain ever - read the white paper to judge for yourself. Join us and build on Telos.

press_kit.description: Everything you need to know about Telos in one PDF.

style_guide.description: A style guide featuring Telos Foundation logos, color palettes and fonts for brand use.

logos_icons.description: A package containing an assortment of file sizes and types for the Telos logo and icon.

banners.heading: Telos Article Splash Banners
banners.subheading: Splash Banner art for use in online articles about Telos.

intro.heading: Dapp Development
intro.subheading: The best network makes the best Dapps
intro.tutorials_description: Learn how to build your Dapp on the Telos network.
intro.smart_contracts_description: Write smart contracts that perform basic Telos functions such as exchanging tokens and casting votes.

gigs.heading: Decentralized gig economies
content: Decentralized gig economies - Telos will lead the emergence of a new and more equitable gig economy; imagine the possibilities of the next Uber or Airbnb led by community ownership and a decentralized workforce.

currency.heading: Currency
content: A stable currency on Telos will open up possibilities to billions of people around the world who don't have access to bank accounts, providing the transparency and decentralization that is needed to prevent financial meltdowns such as the 2008 economic crisis or Venezuela's extreme currency inflation.

records.heading: Decentralized records and information
content: Corruption can be prevented when records are open, transparent and immutable. Information quality can be enhanced by aligned incentive and community efforts. Telos can support vital documents including home ownership registers, medical records, or the next community encyclopedia.

compatibility.heading: EOS Compatibility
content: EOSIO is currently responsible for half of all blockchain transactions and its development is expected to advance faster than older platforms like Ethereum and NEO. The Telos network runs the same EOSIO software as EOS, so Dapps written for EOS can run on Telos. No rewrite needed!

powerful.heading: Powerful performance for decentralized Dapp development
content: Telos facilitates incredibly fast and free transactions to establish a stable and affordable market for Dapp development. RAM supply will be scaled with actual usage in order to ensure affordability and prevent hoarding. Telos tokens have more than three times the resource utility of EOS, and developers will be able to purchase and stake resources such as CPU and bandwidth on behalf of users.

secure.heading: Secure and robust network
content: Telos expands on the EOS network by enforcing additional disclosure requirements and minimum requirements for Telos block producers, who must maintain a full and open testnet in order to support Dapp development. Nonfunctioning block producers are temporarily swapped out after missing just 30 minutes, as opposed to 3 hours on the EOS mainnet, so that developers encounter fewer pauses and problems without compromising security. Fair pay ensures all active and standby block producers are ready to produce at all times for maximum performance and stability.

proprietary.heading: Dapps can be proprietary code
content: Protect your intellectual property with Telos. Unlike EOS, Telos will not force all developers to open source their contract code. This allows commercial Dapp makers to keep other developers from simply copying their work.

decentralized.heading: Decentralized Governance and Arbitration
content: Telos has the most decentralized ownership of any blockchain existing today. No individual or entity will start with, or is likely to ever own, even one percent of the Telos blockchain. Telos’ decentralized voting system ensures that the blockchain is guided by the will of the community and the steady hand of the most competent block producers.

Telos will have a fully developed and ratified Network Operating Agreement and Telos Arbitration Organization (TAO) upon launch. These entities will ensure that conflicts are resolved in a timely manner so that developers can focus on Dapps instead of disputes.

intro.heading: Governance Overview
intro.subheading: Telos is a governed blockchain based on EOSIO - the same software that powers EOS - so that Dapps can deploy on Telos and EOS with the same code. When Telos launches (as early as November 7, 2018) it will have complete documentation and operating structures such as full on-chain governance, the ability to ratify or amend the governance documents by community voting, a worker proposal system, and election of block producers and arbitrators. Below are the main elements and features of blockchain governance on Telos.

documents.heading: THE DOCUMENTS
documents.subheading: The definitions, rules, and procedures of Telos governance are contained in six documents that will be recorded on-chain and modifiable by community vote (pro rata by TLOS token ownership). These documents are:

operating_agreement.long_description: The prime governing document on Telos describing the rights and responsibilities of becoming a member of the Telos Blockchain Network. It is required to opt-in to this agreement in order to access or use Telos. This agreement is the equivalent of the EOS Constitution. It differs from the EOS constitution in form: The TBNOA thoroughly defines all network parts and participants and describes governance actions such as electing block producers, amending the governance documents or submitting a worker proposal system submission. The TBNOA has inherited almost no terms from the EOS Constitution. The TBNOA includes the other five governance documents by reference and each of them adopts its definitions and terms.

arbitration_rules.long_description: The Arbitration Rules & Procedures describes the entire process of arbitration on Telos - from filing a case to procedures for arbitration, to delivery of arbitral judges decisions to block producers for execution. The EOS analog for this is the ECAF Rules and as yet unpublished ECAF Handbook. the Telos Arbitration Rules are entirely independent from the ECAF Rules and share no text. They are also a community amendable core governance document on Telos, whereas the ECAF Rules are set and maintained by the ECAF with no mechanism for input or control from the broader EOS community.
arbitration_rules.short_description: Rules and procedures for arbitration on Telos

regproducer_contract.long_description: The 'regproducer' contract is used by any member desiring to become a block producer candidate to nominate themselves. The human-language terms of this contract set out the responsibilities and rules for block producer candidates. This text is largely inherited from the EOS 'regproducer' contract with much additional text added. The primary difference between the EOS and Telos versions is that while both list prohibited actions, the Telos version also documents penalties for any infractions, the method of enforcement, and the responsibility of block producers to enforce the rules on other BPs.
regproducer_contract.short_description: Rules, responsibilities and representations of block producers

bp_minimums.long_description: The BP Minimum Requirements is a list of disclosures, practices, equipment and networking standards that block producer candidates must adhere to in order to serve. Failure to meet the minimum requirements disqualifies a BP from service until the omission is cured, regardless of how many votes the BP has acquired. Due to the newness of the network, these requirements are described in increasingly stringent phases which the block producers can vote to move between based on 2/3 + 1 voting. EOS does not have minimum requirements or a similar document. A minimum amount of RAM is specified in the EOS 'regproducer' contract.
bp_minimums.short_description: Minimum requirements to act as a block producer

regarb_contract.long_description: The 'regarb' contract is used by any member desiring to become an arbitrator candidate to nominate themselves. The human-language terms of this contract set out the responsibilities and rules for arbitrator candidates. There is no similar document on EOS because EOS does not elect arbitrators.
regarb_contract.short_description: Rules, responsibilities and representations of arbitrators

arbitrator_minimums.long_description: The Arbitrator Minimum Requirements is a list of disclosures, practices, equipment and networking standards that arbitrator candidates must adhere to in order to serve. Failure to meet the minimum requirements disqualifies an arbitrator from being assigned new cases until the omission is cured, regardless of how many votes the arbitrator candidate has acquired. Due to the newness of the network, these requirements are described in increasingly stringent phases. There is no similar document on EOS because EOS does not elect arbitrators.
arbitrator_minimums.short_description: Minimum requirements to act as an arbitrator
